title: Chapter 15 – Classes and Objects Checkpoint
description: Quick concept-check for chapter 15. Test your understanding of classes, __init__, attributes, methods, and objects.

questions.prompt: What is the main purpose of the __init__ method in a Python class?

options.label: To delete an object from memory.
To initialize a new object's attributes when it is created.
To print the object when you call print(obj).

explanations.overview: __init__ runs when a new instance is created and usually sets up its attributes.

byOptionId.a: Deleting is handled differently; __init__ is for setup.
byOptionId.d: __init__ belongs to a class, not to the global scope.

questions.prompt: Which of the following correctly defines a class and its initializer?

explanations.overview: Methods must include self as the first parameter, and __init__ must be inside a class.

byOptionId.a: __init__ is missing self as the first parameter.
byOptionId.b: Correct – this is valid class and __init__ syntax.
byOptionId.c: This defines a function, not a class.
byOptionId.d: This is not valid class syntax in basic Python.

questions.prompt:
Given class Player:
    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name
How do you correctly create a new Player named 'Alex'?

explanations.overview: You create an instance by calling the class like a function.

byOptionId.b: Python does not use new like this for classes.
byOptionId.c: Correct – this calls Player and runs __init__ behind the scenes.
byOptionId.d: There is no built-in init method named this on the class.

questions.prompt: You have p = Player("Alex") and inside __init__ you did self.name = name. How do you read the player's name outside the class?

explanations.overview: Attributes are accessed through the instance variable.

byOptionId.a: Player.name would refer to a class attribute, not the instance's name.
byOptionId.b: self is only used inside class methods.
byOptionId.c: Correct – p.name reads the name attribute from this Player object.
byOptionId.d: This is not valid Python syntax.

questions.prompt: In a method defined as def greet(self):, what does self usually refer to?

options.label: The module where the class is defined.
The specific object (instance) that the method is called on.

explanations.overview: self is the instance that the method is acting on.

byOptionId.a: self is not the class itself, but an instance of it.
byOptionId.b: Modules are separate from class instances.
byOptionId.c: Correct - self lets methods access the instance's data.
byOptionId.d: self is a normal parameter name, not a global variable.

questions.prompt:
You have:

```python
class Hacker:
    team_name = "Red"

    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name

a = Hacker("Alex")
b = Hacker("Blake")
Hacker.team_name = "Blue"
a.name = "Avery"
```

What are the values of a.team_name and b.name at the end?

explanations.overview: Class attributes (like team_name) are shared by all instances. Instance attributes (like name) belong to a single object.

byOptionId.a: Wrong – Hacker.team_name was changed to 'Blue', so a.team_name sees 'Blue'.
byOptionId.b: Correct – class attribute update affects all instances; only a.name was changed.

questions.prompt:
Given:

```python
class Counter:
    def __init__(self):
        self.value = 0

    def click(self):
        self.value = self.value + 1
        return self.value

c = Counter()
x = c.click()
y = c.click()
```

What are the values of x and y?

explanations.overview: Each call to click changes the same object's value and returns the new value after incrementing.

byOptionId.a: Wrong – click starts from 0 and increments, so it never returns 0.
byOptionId.b: Wrong – the second call keeps incrementing, so value becomes 2.
byOptionId.c: Correct – first call returns 1, second call returns 2.
byOptionId.d: Wrong – this would be true only if the counter started at 1.

options.label: self is a keyword that always refers to the class Device.
self is the first argument and refers to the specific Device object that called reboot.
self is a global variable automatically created by Python.
self must always be named self or Python will crash.

explanations.overview: self is just a normal parameter name; by convention it refers to the instance that called the method.

byOptionId.a: Wrong – self is not a keyword and does not always refer to the class.
byOptionId.b: Correct – when you do phone.reboot(), self is that phone object.
byOptionId.c: Wrong – self is not global; it is passed like any other parameter.
byOptionId.d: Wrong – you can use another name, but self is the common convention.

questions.prompt:
Given:

```python
class Bot:
    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name
        self.energy = 100

    def drain(self, amount):
        self.energy = self.energy - amount

a = Bot("Alpha")
b = Bot("Beta")
a.drain(30)
b.drain(10)
```

What are the final energy values?

explanations.overview: Each object has its own energy attribute. The methods modify only the object they’re called on.

byOptionId.a: Wrong – drain was called on both bots, so their energy changed.
byOptionId.d: Wrong – Beta only drained 10, so it should be 90, not 70.
